hawaiian_text: A hala ‘o Puali‘i i ka lawai‘a, i ia wā ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i hele ai me nā keiki he ‘umi  kumamāhiku i nā māla ‘uala a Puali‘i. ‘O ke kino o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ia wā, he kino ‘u‘uku loa, ‘elua  kapua‘i me ka hapa kona ki‘eki‘e, ‘a‘ole i pa‘a kona  ma‘i, e lewalewa ana nō. A hiki lākou i ua māla  ‘uala, kēnā akula ia i nā keiki, “E huhuki i ka pu‘e  me ka lau ‘uala ā pau loa i luna, mai waiho i kekahi e ulu ana.” Akā, maka‘u nō ua keiki, no laila, kāohi  mālie nō ma ka ‘uala, ‘a‘ohe huhuki i ka pu‘e.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_translation: Puli‘i was in the lawai‘a, at that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o went with the children to the taro fields of Puli‘i. The body of Nāmakaokapāo‘o at that time was deep, two-fold with his small mistake, he did not hold his work, only to continue. They arrived at the taro fields, as they were with the children, “Stop the pu‘e with all the taro leaves on top, leave none to grow.” Therefore, only the children, then, only the small and quiet in the taro, no stop in the pu‘e.
qwen3-30b-a3b-awq-128k-maui_commentary:
• [Allegorical interpretation of the narrative as a reflection of resource management and spiritual discipline]  
  – The story of Puli‘i and Nāmakaokapāo‘o navigating taro fields (‘uala) symbolizes the tension between human activity and natural stewardship in traditional Hawaiian society. The "pu‘e" (possibly a sacred site or agricultural practice) represents the sacredness of land and its resources, while the command to "stop the pu‘e with all the taro leaves on top" mirrors the 'Ai Kapu' system’s restrictions on harvesting, emphasizing balance and reverence for the environment.  
  – The phrase "e lewalewa ana nō" (only to continue) suggests a cycle of labor and spiritual obligation, reflecting the kapu’s role in enforcing social and ecological order.  

• [Analysis of character names and symbolism]  
  – **Puli‘i**: "Puli" (to break or to stop) + "‘i" (suffix indicating possession or origin). Symbolizes a guardian of boundaries or a figure enforcing sacred laws.  
  – **Nāmakaokapāo‘o**: "Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o" (the child of the pāo‘o of the sea). "Nāmaka" (sea) and "pāo‘o" (a type of fish or a term for a sacred object) suggest a connection to the ocean and its spiritual significance, possibly representing the interplay between land and sea in Hawaiian cosmology.  
  – **Pu‘e**: A term for a sacred or ritual site, often linked to agricultural practices like taro cultivation, which was central to Hawaiian identity and cosmology.  

• [Historical and cultural context: 'Ai Kapu era and post-1819 transitions]  
  – The narrative reflects the 'Ai Kapu' (food taboo) system, where specific resources were protected by sacred laws. The "small mistake" (hapa kona ki‘eki‘e) might allegorize the consequences of violating these taboos, which were strictly enforced before Kamehameha I’s 1819 abolition of kapu.  
  – The phrase "kāohi mālie nō ma ka ‘uala" (only the small and quiet in the taro) could critique the marginalization of children or marginalized groups under rigid social structures, a theme that gained prominence after missionary contact (post-1820) as traditional hierarchies were challenged.  

• [Numerical symbolism and riddles]  
  – The term "‘elua" (two) may symbolize duality in Hawaiian cosmology, such as the balance between land and sea or the two realms of life (mortal and divine). The "two-fold with his small mistake" might hint at the dual burden of responsibility and error, a common motif in Hawaiian narratives.  
  – The repetition of "no laila" (then) and "kāohi mālie" (small and quiet) underscores the inevitability of consequences, aligning with the Hawaiian concept of *kū* (to stand firm) in the face of divine or social laws.  

• [Social commentary and critique]  
  – The story critiques the rigidity of pre-contact kapu systems, where even minor transgressions (like "ki‘eki‘e," small mistakes) carried severe penalties, reflecting the era’s strict social control.  
  – The mention of children ("keiki") as the focus of the narrative highlights their role as inheritors of tradition, a theme later challenged by missionary influence, which emphasized education and individualism over communal rituals.  
  – The phrase "e lewalewa ana nō" (only to continue) may allegorize the persistence of traditional practices despite external pressures, symbolizing the resilience of *mo‘olelo* (history) in the face of colonialism.

reference_translation: When Puali‘i left to go fishing, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  came with seventeen other children to the sweet  potato patches of Puali‘i. The body of   Nāmakaokapāo‘o at the time was very small, just  two and a half feet tall. His penis was not yet fully  grown and was dangling. When the kids got to the   sweet potato patches, Nāmakaokapāo‘o told the  other kids, “Rip out all of the sweet potato leaves. Don’t leave anything growing.” The children were  afraid and hesitated when they reached the  tubers, and they did not pull those out of the  mound.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 5:**• While Pua-li‘i was away fishing, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  came with 17 other children (perhaps all boys) to the  2 sweet potato patches. The reason they came to the  patches is not stated immediately, but it appears the  reason was to play. The 17 friends of Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o seem to represent the Hawaiian people as a  whole (or perhaps a group of individuals the  storyteller thinks poorly of) allegorically and Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o seems to represent a progressive minded Hawaiian.  • Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o is described at this point of the  story as very small, perhaps 2 feet tall, and that his  penis was not yet fully grown and dangling, likely  meaning he was not wearing a malo.  – The lack of a malo on a boy is descriptive of the  child being too young to wear one. In ‘Ai Kapu  culture, when boys are deemed to be physically  able for chores and work to help sustain the family,  they would go through rites to thrust them into an  age of productive work to help support the family  demonstrated by wearing a malo on a daily basis. It  was a sign of maturity (footnote: Pukui, Haertig, Lee (1972:114) “For the *keiki lewalewa*—usually shortened to *lewalewa*—was yet a “dangler.” A small boy, so young his penis dangled. As a dangler, he wore no  *malo* (loincloth) and he lived and ate with the women. For he was yet *poke‘o*, too young to join the men. ¶ When the little dangler became six or seven years old, his status  changed in one decisive ceremony. This was the *kā i mua*...”);  • The description of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o as a pre malo-wearing child contradicts the maturity and  leadership he demonstrates by his actions and  cognitive skills, where he tells his friends to destroy  the garden. The children demonstrate hesitancy and  destroy the vines and leaves of the sweet potatoes,  but do not dig out the tubers from under the ground. – This likely demonstrates a social rhetorical   commentary about or critique of the ‘Ai Kapu  culture as a whole, that it was worthy of   destruction, with its segregation of men and  women and emphasis on heirarchy, perhaps a  justification for abandoning the culture in 1819\.  The hesitancy of the children, and their depiction in this story as indecisive and timid could be a   Protestant Christian bias (post-1820). The idea of  not pulling out the sweet potato tubers from the  ground could represent not entirely eliminating the  Hawaiian people/culture in the Christian era (not a  complete genocide) despite the biases against the  ‘Ai Kapu;
